quotes.topic_title: Content market fit as product market fit
quotes.text: The way that you think about product market fit, you have to think about content market fit.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Introduces a core framework: treat content like a product that must earn its own market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Content market fit as product market fit
quotes.text: So even though content feels like it's running adjacent to the actual product that you're putting out there, you still have to think about who is my audience?
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that content strategy starts with explicit audience definition, not just product adjacency.

quotes.topic_title: Content market fit as product market fit
quotes.text: What is it that they really need in their lives?
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Pushes practitioners to ground content in real user needs rather than brand messaging or topics-of-interest.

quotes.topic_title: Content market fit as product market fit
quotes.text: What is it that causes them a great deal of anxiety in the day-to-day of their lives or their work?
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A practical lens for finding high-signal content angles: target the audience’s recurring anxieties.

quotes.topic_title: Content market fit as product market fit
quotes.text: And can you create some type of content product that is going to address this for them?
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Frames content as a “product” with a job-to-be-done: directly resolve a specific audience pain point.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: my goal here is to help you get better at the craft of building and growing products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets a practitioner-oriented lens for the episode: improving the craft of product building and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: a guest post in the First Round Review essentially helped me launch my now career of newsletter and now podcast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of how content marketing can create outsized career and distribution outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In this episode, we focus on two areas that Camille was very early in and has tremendous insights around. One, community led growth. What it actually is, when it's something you should invest in, how to do it well.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical decision framework practitioners want: definition, timing, and execution for community-led growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also talk about content marketing. When it's worth investing in, how to do it well, and all kinds of tips for building a content marketing machine.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals actionable guidance on evaluating ROI and operationalizing content into a repeatable system.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific methodology for experimentation analysis: segment results to uncover meaningful differences and root causes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical experimentation best practice: segment results to find meaningful differences across cohorts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, based on our data, about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A concrete retention risk data point that underscores how costly onboarding friction can be.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've consistently seen that improving onboarding is one of the highest leverage opportunities for both signup conversion and increasing long-term retention.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear prioritization heuristic for growth teams: focus on onboarding to move both conversion and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So making sure that I knew everything that could possibly come up in a conversation, being incredibly well-versed in just the topics at hand, I think that served me really well.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Actionable preparation model for high-stakes comms: anticipate questions and master the full surface area of likely topics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: painting an emotional picture of the vision that he was really going after and being able to convey the emotional quality of the mission to the people he talked to.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A messaging framework: pair facts with an emotionally resonant mission to recruit “hearts and minds.”

quotes.topic_title: Camille’s career path: journalism to Notion
quotes.text: I feel like it's been a quite circuitous path, but definitely has taken me to some interesting places.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that non-linear career paths can be an asset rather than a liability.

quotes.topic_title: Camille’s career path: journalism to Notion
quotes.text: I started off as a journalist at the Wall Street Journal and then found my way into communications and marketing at Tesla Motors where part of my responsibility there was to sit to Elon's right and make sure he had all the data he needed at his fingertips when talking to the press, which was deep end of the pool on the PR learning.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A concrete, actionable example of “exec enablement”: equipping a spokesperson with ready-to-use data for high-stakes press interactions.

quotes.topic_title: Camille’s career path: journalism to Notion
quotes.text: found my way to First Round Capital where I was really fortunate to be at the ground floor of First Round Review, if anyone out there watching this is familiar with those pieces.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Highlights the leverage of building a durable content platform early (“ground floor”) as a career and company-building accelerant.

quotes.topic_title: Camille’s career path: journalism to Notion
quotes.text: And then they had invested in Notion really early on, and so I was able to meet Ivan Zhao as a result of that and him and Simon, and they gave me the opportunity to join as the first marketing hire at Notion.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A specific example of how network adjacency (via an investor) can create high-leverage opportunities like being a first marketing hire.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Tesla and working with Elon
quotes.text: But in terms of what I learned, that was really the first job that I had that was necessitating just being incredibly on point with all the information.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner-level standard for high-stakes comms: mastery of details as a baseline requirement.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Tesla and working with Elon
quotes.text: So making sure that I knew everything that could possibly come up in a conversation, being incredibly well-versed in just the topics at hand, I think that served me really well.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A concrete preparation methodology: anticipate all likely questions and build comprehensive topic fluency.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Tesla and working with Elon
quotes.text: And then the other thing that Elon I think is very talented at or definitely at the time really made an impression on me was painting an emotional picture of the vision that he was really going after and being able to convey the emotional quality of the mission to the people he talked to.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A repeatable messaging model: pair vision with emotional resonance to mobilize audiences beyond facts.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Tesla and working with Elon
quotes.text: I think that that was the place where you just needed to be so on your game. Game face every single day.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Captures the operational expectation of sustained high performance as a learned skill in intense environments.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Tesla and working with Elon
quotes.text: So a lot of my work was, and this was a great opportunity, but driving around in the Roadster and talking to journalists and letting reporters ride in the car, which was very seductive and I think maybe just a little unfair from a PR standpoint.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A specific example of product-led PR: using firsthand experience to create an advantage in media narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Early Notion: employee 11 and startup life
quotes.text: I was number 11.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A concrete data point that underscores how early she joined and how small the team was when foundational culture and practices were set.

quotes.topic_title: Early Notion: employee 11 and startup life
quotes.text: The last I heard, I think that they were around 400. Maybe a little over 400.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A scale marker practitioners can use to contextualize the growth arc from an 11-person startup to a mid-sized company.

quotes.topic_title: Early Notion: employee 11 and startup life
quotes.text: So during the summer it was really hot and then in the winter it was really cold and we would have these big industrial fans and at the time we were like, "Oh, this is really bizarre." But now it's one of our favorite memories to talk about.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A vivid example of how shared hardship can become a bonding mechanism and later a cultural story that strengthens team identity.

quotes.topic_title: Early Notion: employee 11 and startup life
quotes.text: Or for a while we didn't have overhead lighting, so me and my colleagues who were there working really late at night, it would just get darker and darker and darker. And one of my favorite folks there actually had a headlamp that she would switch on at a certain point in the evening.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A specific, memorable illustration of scrappy startup constraints—and how teams adapt operationally while building camaraderie.

quotes.topic_title: Early Notion: employee 11 and startup life
quotes.text: But looking back, it's always the best memories, those hardships.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that reframes painful early-stage constraints as future cultural assets and retention-worthy stories.

quotes.topic_title: Notion outage: crisis response and community support
quotes.text: And it really reinforced for us how central Notion had become to so many people.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A crisis can function as a real-time “importance audit,” revealing how mission-critical your product is to users.

quotes.topic_title: Notion outage: crisis response and community support
quotes.text: So on one hand it was kind of this amazing moment of realization of how vital this thing we were building was all the time, which adds to the stress in the moment, but also your motivation overall.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Reframes outages as dual-signal events: they increase pressure but also validate product value and strengthen team drive.

quotes.topic_title: Notion outage: crisis response and community support
quotes.text: But that day was definitely a scramble and we wanted to be as communicative as possible.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Highlights a practical crisis-response principle: prioritize frequent, transparent communication during incidents.

quotes.topic_title: Notion outage: crisis response and community support
quotes.text: I think that's a good tactical learning and hopefully a takeaway for folks who maybe will experience that moment is that truly there's more resilience built into the system than you might think.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A calming mental model for incident management: user churn fears are often overstated because strong products have built-in recovery momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Defining community-led growth and measuring discovery
quotes.text: it's when your community helps you achieve such ubiquity and such name recognition that it actually allows you to start moving upmarket into the enterprise.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Defines community-led growth as a mechanism for ubiquity that unlocks enterprise adoption (a clear, outcome-based framework).

quotes.topic_title: Defining community-led growth and measuring discovery
quotes.text: I love using the word discovery because I think that that is even a little bit like a step further than awareness where true discovery is when you have intent to find out more.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Introduces a sharper mental model than “awareness” by tying success to user intent, not just impressions.

quotes.topic_title: Defining community-led growth and measuring discovery
quotes.text: And the one that I found to be the most instructive was net new visitors to the Notion website. So month over month, how many new people who had never been there before were motivated enough to come and actually learn about the product.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Gives a practical KPI for measuring discovery/brand work using a concrete, trackable metric.

quotes.topic_title: Defining community-led growth and measuring discovery
quotes.text: In particular I'll call out the influencer marketing efforts that were really being run by this incredible woman, Lexi Barnhorn, where they were incredibly measurable. Where we were like, okay, well we're sponsoring people for this amount, these creators across these platforms and we know that people came from that content directly to the Notion website.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Provides a specific example of a brand/community-adjacent channel (influencers) that can be tightly attributed to site traffic.

quotes.topic_title: What worked at Notion: ambassadors, events, influencers
quotes.text: So I'd say that the community efforts that were very big for us we're the ambassadors. Also making sure that people were hosting in-person events.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Highlights the two highest-impact community levers Notion prioritized: ambassadors and in-person events.

quotes.topic_title: What worked at Notion: ambassadors, events, influencers
quotes.text: he says that they're back up to 30 in-person events a month around the world.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Provides a concrete scale benchmark for what a mature, global community events engine can look like.

quotes.topic_title: What worked at Notion: ambassadors, events, influencers
quotes.text: So really helping us work our way into those types of networks and then supporting those people to also start their own businesses and derive whatever reward they were looking for themselves. So we really wanted to align our goals with theirs.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Offers a clear incentive-alignment model: grow by helping community members achieve their own outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: What worked at Notion: ambassadors, events, influencers
quotes.text: A lot of those folks actually started revenue generating businesses as consultants or course makers or influencers.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Shows how community programs can create economic upside for members, strengthening participation and advocacy.

quotes.topic_title: What worked at Notion: ambassadors, events, influencers
quotes.text: we were so pleasantly overwhelmed with the amount of traction and traffic that was driven by working with some of these influencers.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Underscores influencer partnerships as a surprisingly powerful growth channel when executed well.

quotes.topic_title: ROI, founder belief, and when community fits
quotes.text: one of my number one recommendations for anybody who suspects the community could be a big growth driver is to not make metrics the be all end all at the very beginning.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to avoid over-measuring community too early so you don’t prematurely kill a promising growth channel.

quotes.topic_title: ROI, founder belief, and when community fits
quotes.text: I think for any company that is seeing this type of just organic fervor, one of the worst things you can do is say, let's cut this off at the knees if it's not generating ROI.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Warns practitioners not to shut down community efforts just because ROI isn’t immediately provable when organic momentum is evident.

quotes.topic_title: ROI, founder belief, and when community fits
quotes.text: Definitely I think if you have a long sales cycle or a high price point where there has to be many, many, many touchpoints in order to get somebody to decide to buy, I'm not sure that community should be the number one thing that you invest in.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A practical prioritization rule: community may be a weaker primary bet for high-touch, long-cycle sales motions.

quotes.topic_title: ROI, founder belief, and when community fits
quotes.text: Certainly for freemium products, I think for a lot of them, especially if they have what I'm going to call the atomic unit of sharing, which I will define out, it becomes a no-brainer.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Introduces a useful framework (“atomic unit of sharing”) for deciding when community is likely to drive growth in PLG/freemium products.

quotes.topic_title: ROI, founder belief, and when community fits
quotes.text: I think that community lends itself particularly well if you have something that your product creates that people want to share because it exhibits something about themselves.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A clear heuristic: community works best when the product output is inherently shareable and identity/aspiration-signaling.

quotes.topic_title: Notion creator economy: templates and consultants
quotes.text: Yeah. This is one of the reasons that I would advise any of the companies that feel like they fall into this category start early. Because you need to nurture all of these different routes that people in your community can take.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Actionable advice to invest early in multiple community-driven monetization paths to strengthen the ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: Notion creator economy: templates and consultants
quotes.text: I remember really early on, probably mid 2021 we heard of one creator who had made $35,000 in four months selling one template and that was a very common story then from that point forward.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Concrete data point illustrating how meaningful income can emerge from a template marketplace and fuel creator participation.

quotes.topic_title: Notion creator economy: templates and consultants
quotes.text: And helping them do that, actually creating the guide material and the networks and also the connections between the people who are running similar businesses who could help each other, that all became really fundamental.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A practical methodology: enable creators with playbooks plus peer networks so they can scale and support each other.

quotes.topic_title: Notion creator economy: templates and consultants
quotes.text: So many companies now of many sizes are relying on the consultants that first came up through our community and some of those consultants are now employing dozens of other people.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Shows how community-grown consultants can become a de facto implementation channel that accelerates enterprise adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Notion creator economy: templates and consultants
quotes.text: There's no better way to motivate someone to evangelize Notion than have their income rely on Notion.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable, slightly contrarian growth lever: align evangelism incentives by enabling users to earn money from the product ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: Ambassadors vs champions: program structures
quotes.text: So we would actually have channels inside of our Slack instance for the ambassadors that had these areas of focus based on what people really were passionate about or wanted to do and they were like a force multiplying flywheel for each other.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A concrete community design pattern: segment members by passion/intent and let peer-to-peer momentum compound.

quotes.topic_title: Ambassadors vs champions: program structures
quotes.text: So on the champions side of things, and this is maybe speaking a little bit more to the enterprise as well, we wondered if the same DNA that existed among consumers for the most part in the ambassadors could work for folks who were inside of our customer companies.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A transferable mental model: adapt consumer community dynamics to enterprise by targeting internal power users.

quotes.topic_title: Ambassadors vs champions: program structures
quotes.text: They're people who are really just passionate about the product. So it's not transactional.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Clarifies the non-obvious distinction between ambassadors and paid promotion—optimize for intrinsic motivation, not incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Ambassadors vs champions: program structures
quotes.text: But over time it was really because they were forming these bonds with each other and learning so much from each other that most of the time someone would come in and say, I'm struggling with this or I don't quite know how to use this and it would be another member of the community that would help them more immediately.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Shows how community becomes a scalable support engine: peer help resolves issues faster than the company can.

quotes.topic_title: Ambassadors vs champions: program structures
quotes.text: I would recommend highly not necessarily coming in with preconceived notions about what a community needs to look like.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Practical guidance for operators: avoid one-size-fits-all community playbooks and let member needs shape the program.

quotes.topic_title: How to build community: listen, don’t prescribe
quotes.text: I think Ben was best at is not putting a one size fits all experience on any of this.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A core community-building principle: avoid prescribing a single “correct” community experience and design for what members actually need.

quotes.topic_title: How to build community: listen, don’t prescribe
quotes.text: Really early on one of the things that Ben did that I thought was really amazing was he'd spend a ton of time just on Zoom having conversations, one-on-one conversations, semi small group conversations just saying, "Why are you here? Why do you like participating in this? What is it that would make it better?"
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable method for shaping community strategy: direct 1:1 and small-group listening to uncover motivations and improvements.

quotes.topic_title: How to build community: listen, don’t prescribe
quotes.text: I would recommend highly not necessarily coming in with preconceived notions about what a community needs to look like.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Practical guidance to start from member signals rather than a predesigned program template.

quotes.topic_title: How to build community: listen, don’t prescribe
quotes.text: I would really urge people to sit down and really think carefully what is going to be more conducive to our long-term success? Is it going to be that ubiquity or is it going to be revenue now?
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A decision framework for founders: explicitly choose between optimizing for word-of-mouth ubiquity vs near-term monetization.

quotes.topic_title: How to build community: listen, don’t prescribe
quotes.text: It becomes this buttress for any paid growth you explore in the future.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A mental model for sequencing growth: build an organic flywheel first to strengthen and de-risk later paid acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Community examples and a two-by-two framework
quotes.text: So I would encourage anyone who's thinking about community that way to be like, "Oh, maybe it doesn't have to be around our product. So specifically. What other knowledge or resourcing can we offer to the people who we do want using our product that's going to be really instrumental for them and can we convene them around that idea?"
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice that community can be built around adjacent value (knowledge/resources), not just the product itself.

quotes.topic_title: Community examples and a two-by-two framework
quotes.text: But I do think the community takes on different forms and I think when you hear the word community, you think of a big forum of some type, whether it's a Slack instance or something else where people are chatting away all day long. And I don't think it has to be that. That's not the only representation of it.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Reframes “community” beyond forums/Slack, opening up alternative, more practical implementations.

quotes.topic_title: Community examples and a two-by-two framework
quotes.text: So if you think about what is going to be right for you at any given time, I actually created this two by two matrix, which maybe I'll share with you after this. And on the axis you have, whether you have hit product market fit or if you're still exploring product market set and then whether you're strongly enterprise or strongly consumer. And based on where you land in that two by two matrix, there's a form of community or a community related initiative that could be right for you.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A clear 2x2 framework (PMF vs pre-PMF; enterprise vs consumer) for selecting the right community approach.

quotes.topic_title: Community examples and a two-by-two framework
quotes.text: I think that you have the opportunity to do customer advisory boards, which is really convening even smaller circles of ideal fit users and making sure that they are connected to each other as well as you, and then incentivize to provide you with feedback.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Actionable tactic for pre-PMF enterprise: use CABs as a structured, small-scale community to accelerate learning and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Community examples and a two-by-two framework
quotes.text: So if you're strongly enterprise and you have product market fit, let's say, this is something that Notion has really benefited from, but really emphasizing the champions in the consultants communities.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Practical guidance for post-PMF enterprise: invest in internal champions and external consultants as scalable community levers.

quotes.topic_title: Designing an ambassador program and keeping it healthy
quotes.text: I actually think it's pretty analogous to when you're thinking about positioning your company because I think the best first step for any positioning exercise is to think who are our best fit customers? And it's not necessarily who we wish they would be, but it's actually the hard cold reality of who they actually are.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Frames ambassador selection as a positioning exercise: start from who already gets value, not an aspirational persona.

quotes.topic_title: Designing an ambassador program and keeping it healthy
quotes.text: So the initial base of the ambassadors program which started back in 2019 was just 20 people and they were the 20 people who we happened to see be the most vocal already across Twitter and a couple of other social media platforms because they had that shared quality of wanting to be really vocal and expressive about their experience with the product.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Gives a concrete starting point and selection heuristic: begin small and recruit from already-vocal organic advocates.

quotes.topic_title: Designing an ambassador program and keeping it healthy
quotes.text: And it was so interesting to us how giving them the preview of features was so motivating to them and being able to use them and then give us feedback and feel really heard by the product team.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Highlights a high-leverage incentive: early feature access plus a tight feedback loop with the product team.

quotes.topic_title: Designing an ambassador program and keeping it healthy
quotes.text: So don't dilute the impact of what it is that you're trying to do in order to show growth.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: A clear commandment for community programs: resist chasing early metrics that weaken the experience.

quotes.topic_title: Designing an ambassador program and keeping it healthy
quotes.text: I think ironically, and then I'll stop rambling about this, but if you grow to something like, oh we have 5,000 ambassadors, which feels really good to say on a website, the conversation is actually very muted. I think because people feel like they're speaking to an auditorium whenever they say anything.
quotes.speaker: Camille Ricketts
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that scaling community too fast can reduce participation and intimacy.
